prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band3 (N2H+)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 3 to target N2H+. The spectral window also covers HC3N, CH3CN, CH3CCH.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our velocity resolution (< 4km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities in the expected line width of 50 km/s. We do not lower the resolution further because we could obtain some velocity information for lines that have high enough intensity. This a reasonable value while it does not exceed the data rate too much more than the maximum.
-rep. spec. window width We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
Since our target molecules usually traces dense and compact region, we expect emissions are mostly coming from GMC scale (~1.5"). Therefore, LAS must be not larger than ~7".

Sensitivity: We used the CN intensity of ALMA cycle 0 archive data (2011.0.00772.S) to estimate the intensity of other molecules observed by a single-dish line survey in 3mm band with IRAM 30 m telescope by Aladro et al. (A&A, submitted). The velocity-integrated intensity of CN (1_3/2 - 0_1/2) line at 113.5 GHz was 50 K km/s within their ~2.3"x1.3" beam with the line width of 50 km/s in ALMA cycle 0 data. This line has a velocity-integrated intensity of 12.6 K km/s in a single-dish survey while our target line N2H+ has 1.2 K km/s. Since the single-dish data has a bigger beam size at lower frequency, the beam dilution is more in lower frequency. Taking that to an account, we calculate an rms for 10 sigma detection of N2H+ at a few GMCs with strongest emission to also observe GMCs with lower intensity. We need: rms = (50 K km/s / 50 km/s)*(1.2 K/12.6 K)*(113.5GHz/93.2GHz)^2 *(1/10) = 14 mK (~0.28mJy). Since we assume that the source size of GMCs are about our beam size (1.5") and all the emission is coming from those regions, we estimate the emission to be this value in Jy units. According to OT, the observing time suddenly increases from 1.3 h to 1.7h when the required rms is changed from 0.3mJy to 0.28mJy because the number of SB increases. For this reason, we request 0.30 mJy instead of 0.28 mJy, which gives us 9.3 sigma detection instead of 10 sigma.
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.
We hope to obtain velocity information for lines intense enough. Our data rate in this science goal is 12.21 GB, which only slightly exceeds the limit of 12GB.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band7 (HCN, HCO+, CS)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 7 to target HCN, HCO+, and CS.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our velocity resolution (~2 km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities as well as some velocity information in the expected line width of 50 km/s within the data rate limit.
-Representative spectral window width: We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
Since our target molecules usually traces dense and compact region, we expect emissions are mostly coming from GMC scale (~1.5"). Therefore, LAS must be not larger than ~7".

Sensitivity: In SMA data by Sakamoto et al., the intensity of CS(7-6) was 0.1 K at the peak position within 1.9"x1.3" beam, equivalent to our beam size. Our requested sensitivity of 1.5mJy/bm (=7mK) will have 14 sigma detection at the peak, which will allow enough detection in GMCs other than those peak position.
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band7 (N2H+,CS)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 7 to target N2H+ and CS.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolution:Our velocity resolution (~2 km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities as well as some velocity information in the expected line width of 50 km/s within the data rate limit.
-Representative spectral window width: We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
-LAS: Since our target molecules usually traces dense and compact region, we expect emissions are mostly coming from GMC scale (~1.5"). Therefore, LAS must be not larger than ~7".

Sensitivity: In SMA data by Sakamoto et al., the intensity of CS(7-6) was 0.1 K at the peak position within 1.9"x1.3" beam, equivalent to our beam size. Our requested sensitivity of 1.5mJy/bm (=7mK) will have 14 sigma detection at the peak, which will allow enough detection in GMCs other than those peak position. We assume that N2H+ (3-2) and CS(6-5) have similar intensity comparing other line surveys in the 1mm band.
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6(H2CO,13CO)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 6 to target H2CO, 13CO, C18O. The spectral window also covers SiO, HNCO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolution: Our velocity resolution (~2.5 km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities as well as some velocity information in the expected line width of 50 km/s within the data rate limit.
-Representative spectral window width: We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
-LAS:From the SMA data of CO (2-1) by Sakamoto et al., the structure seem to extend up to ~ 10"

Sensitivity: In SMA data by Sakamoto et al., the intensity of C18O(2-1) was 166mJy/beam within the 2.2" x 1.8" beam. If we assume most of the emission is coming from ~1.5" GMC core, our requested rms of 0.7mJy over 50 km/s will be able to detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1) with 10 sigma. Although there is no single-dish survey in Band 6 frequency, the intensity ratios between molecules are similar to 3mm survey, all the lines detected in the 3mm survey should be detectable. Although some molecules are harder to detect in higher frequencies, comparing with a single dish survey of NGC 253 in 1mm band, we should still be able to detect 13CO, HCN, HCO+, HNC, CH3OH, H2CO, CS, CN if we can detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1).
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6(CN)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 6 to target CN. The spectral window also covers HC3N, CH3CN, and HNCO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolution: Our velocity resolution (~2.5 km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities as well as some velocity information in the expected line width of 50 km/s within the data rate limit.
-Representative spectral window width: We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
From the SMA data of CO (2-1) by Sakamoto et al., the structure seem to extend up to ~ 10"

Sensitivity:In SMA data by Sakamoto et al., the intensity of C18O(2-1) was 166mJy/beam within the 2.2" x 1.8" beam. If we assume most of the emission is coming from ~1.5" GMC core, our requested rms of 0.7mJy over 50 km/s will be able to detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1) with 10 sigma. Although there is no single-dish survey in Band 6 frequency, the intensity ratios between molecules are similar to 3mm survey, all the lines detected in the 3mm survey should be detectable. Although some molecules are harder to detect in higher frequencies, comparing with a single dish survey of NGC 253 in 1mm band, we should still be able to detect 13CO, HCN, HCO+, HNC, CH3OH, H2CO, CS, CN if we can detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1).
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6(HNC)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 6 to target HNC. The spectral window also covers HC3N, CH3CN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolution: Our velocity resolution (~2.5 km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities as well as some velocity information in the expected line width of 50 km/s within the data rate limit.
-Representative spectral window width: We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
-LAS: Since our target molecules usually traces dense and compact region, we expect emissions are mostly coming from GMC scale (~1.5"). Therefore, LAS must be not larger than ~7".

Sensitivity: In SMA data by Sakamoto et al., the intensity of C18O(2-1) was 166mJy/beam within the 2.2" x 1.8" beam. If we assume most of the emission is coming from ~1.5" GMC core, our requested rms of 0.7mJy over 50 km/s will be able to detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1) with 10 sigma. Although there is no single-dish survey in Band 6 frequency, the intensity ratios between molecules are similar to 3mm survey, all the lines detected in the 3mm survey should be detectable. Although some molecules are harder to detect in higher frequencies, comparing with a single dish survey of NGC 253 in 1mm band, we should still be able to detect 13CO, HCN, HCO+, HNC, CH3OH, H2CO, CS, CN if we can detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1).
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6(C2H,CS)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 6 to target C2H and CS. The spectral window also covers SiO, HNCO, and HC3N.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolution:Our velocity resolution (~2.5 km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities as well as some velocity information in the expected line width of 50 km/s within the data rate limit.
-Representative spectral window width: We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
-LAS:Since our target molecules usually traces dense and compact region, we expect emissions are mostly coming from GMC scale (~1.5"). Therefore, LAS must be not larger than ~7".

Sensitivity:In SMA data by Sakamoto et al., the intensity of C18O(2-1) was 166mJy/beam within the 2.2" x 1.8" beam. If we assume most of the emission is coming from ~1.5" GMC core, our requested rms of 0.7mJy over 50 km/s will be able to detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1) with 10 sigma. Although there is no single-dish survey in Band 6 frequency, the intensity ratios between molecules are similar to 3mm survey, all the lines detected in the 3mm survey should be detectable. Although some molecules are harder to detect in higher frequencies, comparing with a single dish survey of NGC 253 in 1mm band, we should still be able to detect 13CO, HCN, HCO+, HNC, CH3OH, H2CO, CS, CN if we can detect lines with 24 times less intensity than C18O(2-1).
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band3 (13CO, CS, CH3OH)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It observes M 83 in Band 3 to target 13CO, CS, and CH3OH. The spectral window also covers HC3N, HNCO, and CH3CN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolution:Our velocity resolution (< 4km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities in the expected line width of 50 km/s. We do not lower the resolution further because we could obtain some velocity information for lines that have high enough intensity. This a reasonable value while it does not exceed the data rate too much more than the maximum.
-Representative spectral window width: We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Angular resolution: we use an angular resolution of 1".5 (= 33 pc) in all bands to resolve GMC-scale clumps.
-LAS:Since our target molecules usually traces dense and compact region, we expect emissions are mostly coming from GMC scale (~1.5"). Therefore, LAS must be not larger than ~7".

We used the CN intensity of ALMA cycle 0 archive data (2011.0.00772.S) to estimate the intensity of other molecules observed by a single-dish line survey in 3mm band with IRAM 30 m telescope by Aladro et al. (A&A, in press). The velocity-integrated intensity of CN (1_3/2 - 0_1/2) line at 113.5 GHz was 50 K km/s within their ~2.3"x1.3" beam with the line width of 50 km/s in ALMA cycle 0 data at a few GMCs with strongest emission. This line has a velocity-integrated intensity of 12.6 K km/s in a single-dish survey while our target line CH3OH at 96.7 GHz has 1.1 K km/s. Since the single-dish data has a bigger beam size at lower frequency, the beam dilution is more in lower frequency. Taking that to an account, we calculate an rms for 10 sigma detection of CH3OH at a few GMCs with strongest emission to also observe GMCs with lower intensity. We need: rms = (50 K km/s / 50 km/s)*(1.1 K/12.6 K)*(113.5GHz/96.7GHz)^2 *(1/10) = 12 mK (=0.26mJy/bm). Since we assume that the source size of GMCs are about our beam size (1.5") and all the emission is coming from those regions, we use this value in Jy units.
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Our main target science is studied by using the velocity-integrated intensity, and we use the line width taken from ALMA cycle 0 archival data for our sensitivity calculation.
We hope to obtain velocity information for lines intense enough. Our data rate in this science goal is 12.21 GB, which only slightly exceeds the limit of 12GB.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
M 83 is the best ALMA target to study spatially-resolved chemistry in the nuclear region of a starburst galaxy. This is because of its proximity, face-on configuration and brightness. It has been proposed from near infrared/optical/UV observations that the gas flowing through the bar into the circumnuclear ring can induce active star formation.This creates an age gradient of stars along the circumnuclear ring.
We propose to observe molecular tracers to examine whether chemical composition along the circum-nuclear ring can be used to probe such a time difference in star formation.In several frequency settings in Band 3, 6, and 7, we will map molecular tracers of shocks, photon-dominated regions, dense cores, at the GMC-scale.
Our chemical diagnostics can reveal the star formation sequence even in regions of high obscuration where light at other wavelengths cannot convey the information. This dataset will also serve as a chemical template in the circumnuclear ring of a starburst galaxy with much better spatial information, sensitivity, and chemical complexity than previous studies.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
